From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From inspire +‎ -er.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Rhymes: -aɪəɹə(ɹ)

Noun

[edit]

inspirer (plural inspirers)

  1. Someone who inspires.
    • 1879, F. D. Morice, Pindar, chapter 8, page 123:
      Iamus, the legendary ancestor of this priestly house, was a son of Apollo, the god of divination, and inspirer of the great oracle at Delphi.

Translations

[edit]
someone who inspires
  • German: Inspirator m, Inspiratorin f
  • Greek: εμπνευστής (el) m (empnefstís)
  • Hindi: प्रेरक (hi) m (prerak)
  • Latvian: inspirators m, inspiratore f
  • Macedonian: вдахно́вител m (vdahnóvitel), вдахнови́телка f (vdahnovítelka), вдахно́вувач m (vdahnóvuvač), вдахнову́вачка f (vdahnovúvačka)
  • Russian: вдохнови́тель (ru) m (vdoxnovítelʹ), вдохнови́тельница (ru) f (vdoxnovítelʹnica)
  • Spanish: inspirador (es) m, inspiradora (es) f
  • Swedish: inspiratör (sv) c

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin īnspīrāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ɛ̃s.pi.ʁe/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

inspirer

  1. to breathe in
    Coordinate term: expirer
  2. to inspire
    inspirer confiance à quelqu'un ― to inspire confidence in someone, to inspire trust in someone
    Ça ne m'inspire guère confiance. ― That doesn't inspire much confidence in me.

compound — simple imperative of avoir + past participle — simple imperative of avoir + past participle simple imperative of avoir + past participle —
1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Latin

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

īnspīrer

  1. first-person singular present passive subjunctive of īnspīrō

Norwegian Bokmål

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

inspirer

  1. imperative of inspirere
